Many years ago, I managed a small restaurant. One of the young ladies who worked for me approached me one day and she was visibly upset. She knew that I was a preacher and said that she needed to talk with me. Her father and boyfriend had both pressured her into having an abortion. She didn‚Äôt want to go through with it but, like many young women, she felt that she had no choice. Her regret and anguish was heartbreaking. I prayed with her and spent time listening to her. I assured her that Jesus still loves her and it seemed to help that she could share her feelings of guilt without being judged by the listener. A few days later, one of our regular customers, a mean and bitter lady, was bragging to another customer in line about her work with the local abortion clinic. I overheard the conversation and pointed out to her about the terrible after effects many women go through. She looked me right in the eye and said that she had never heard of such. I asked my young employee to tell her about the experience that she was going through. The old bitty shut up. She also never came back to our restaurant. That was fine with me. The young lady told me that telling her story to an abortion activist helped her even more and that she was determined to tell other women about the aftermath of having killed your child. I‚Äôve since been told by other women their stories of having constant nightmares where they could hear their child crying or asking them why they were killed, why didn‚Äôt they love them. If a woman has an even partially functioning soul, they will experience extreme guilt, loss and heartbreak. Sadly, many have taken their own lives because of their feelings of guilt.
